At Dragonfly, we work with students and professionals to tackle performance challenges in real time. That means our aim today is to help you get the ball rolling on whatever it is you’re calling about. Motivation - Finish Early
Setting a self-imposed deadline earlier than the class deadline is a good way of motivating yourself to finish work you’d otherwise put off doing.

Finishing early is a test of your ability to turn your intentions into actions. Self-imposed deadlines allow you to take action within your environment instead of reacting to it. Here is how this would work:
Make your due date 1 class period sooner than the current deadline. (if class is once a week make your deadline a week sooner…if class is MWF and current due date is F change it to W).
Set a reward  (Food/entertainment/trip/workout) for when you finish.
Set a countdown to how many days you have until your new deadline.
Specify daily goals (aligned with countdown) you want to accomplish for that assignment

Ideally, when you’re creating a schedule, you want to set regular times for working on certain tasks. Planning the same task at about the same time creates consistency that, in the long term, can help turn that task into a habit.

For instance, if you plan to set aside two hours every evening to study your biology notes, you might find that at first it’s really hard to get yourself to do it. But, after a few weeks, it starts to become easier until, eventually, it feels automatic to do it.
Research shows that it can take anywhere from 18 to 66 days to form a new habit.
Ideally, your schedule will help encourage the creation of productive habits like this.

There are three ways we deal with distractions:
We can react to them, which we don't want to do, or
We can prepare for them, or
We can limit their control over our goals.
So, let’s talk about a few techniques you can use to prepare for your distractions in order to limit their control over your goals.
First, and possibly most importantly, is that you can
Set aside time specifically for your distractions
Realistically, the things that distract us aren’t going away, right?
You’ll always have family or friendship obligations that will require your time.
Social media isn’t going away.
The internet, video games, movies, TV shows… all of these things are going to try to capture our attention.
Instead of approaching the things that distract you as if you could cut them out of your life, try scheduling specific times for your distractions.

This might mean setting aside time every day for a social media break, or to call your family, or making sure to reserve one evening a week for playing video games or for just doing something for yourself.
Let’s try scheduling some time during your week for your most common distractions.

Practice saying “No” to distractions EXCEPT for during the scheduled time.

Lead with your goals, which means: Let your actions be defined by your goals.

So, when you’ve been successful at saying no to your distractions during those times when you’re supposed to be working toward your goal: reward yourself!

While preparation is important,
Note-taking is an essential skill.
Studies show that handwritten notes are more effective than taking notes on the computer.
If you are able, we recommend taking notes by hand instead of on the computer.
I recommend using the Cornell Note Taking Method because it helps prioritize specific actions that really work with effective learning practices.
Here’s how it works.
Whenever you turn to a new page of your notebook, you’ll divide the paper into 4 sections:
a header at the top
a footer at the bottom, and
2 columns dividing the space in the middle
a narrower, marginal column on the Left that is still wide enough to add questions and additional comments after the lecture or class, and
a wider one to the right where the main body of your notes will go.
If you’re using standard lined paper, you can use the red line going down the left side of the sheet as a guide for separating the two columns.

The header section is for your class title and the date. You could add other identifying information to help you quickly access the information later, like the lecture title or the main topics covered.

The larger, right-hand column is for your own notes during the lecture. If your instructor is delivering the lecture using PowerPoint slides or another presentation software, don’t copy down the information on the slides word for work. Put information in your own words using concise sentences and keywords that can jog your memory later.
We’ll talk about what you do with the other two columns next, when we talk about how to best structure individual study sessions.

Before we dive too deep into some skills and practices you can use to supercharge your learning, let’s talk briefly about some mental and physical preparation you can do to help you perform at your best.
Physical Preparation
Drink.
Plenty of water throughout the day;
Eat.
Try to eat brain foods like plenty of fruits and vegetables, and oily fish for their omega-3 fatty acids;
Smaller meals with snacks in between are recommended, because larger meals can lead to drowsiness and lower concentration;
Exercise.
Even just ten minutes here or there can help you stay focused and keep your mind working more efficiently.
Incorporate exercise into your day by exercising before or after study sessions, or during short breaks.
Types of exercise: short walks, seat calisthenics, push-ups, etc.
Sleep.
7-9 hours per night;

Taking control of your goals and the path you take to get to your goals is an important first step to success. This means you have to embody the idea that the goals you set and the steps you take to get there matter.
How does time management fit into this? Well, proper time management can help save you time and effort by using your available time and effort efficiently.

So let’s focus on some things you can do to practice control over your time.
, you can create and maintain a schedule or calendar.
This sounds simple, and it is. But it can also be incredibly important for developing a sense of control.

When you create a schedule or calendar, you are literally organizing your time. Of course, there are things you will have to do - class times, work shifts, other responsibilities - but there will also be chunks of time that you will be fully in charge of. That doesn’t mean you can do anything you want in those times (you still have responsibilities), but you do control them, and by consciously scheduling those times you are asserting that control.
, you can write your own earlier deadlines for course assignments.

I know it sounds bonkers to do work early, but this isn’t about trying to be a great student; it’s about taking control of your time. If you create your own deadlines, you’re asserting that much more control over your time.
Your deadlines don’t have to be that much earlier, either. If you have an assignment due at noon, you could set yourself a deadline to do it by eleven.
, you can share your plans with others.
This lets others know (and yourself know) that you are in charge of your own time.
